End of 3rd week of intrauterine life to end of 8th week of intrauterine life
Beginning of 3rd week of intrauterine life to Beginning of 8th week of intrauterine life

questions.text: Which of the following is embryonic period?
questions.solution:
Stages of Development

  • Pre-Embryonic Period
    • Duration: Conception to the end of the second week of intrauterine life (IUL).
    • Key Events:
      • Fertilization
      • Transport of zygote through the uterine tube
      • Mitotic divisions (cleavage)
      • Implantation
      • Formation of primordial embryonic tissues
    • Embryonic Period
      • Duration: Beginning of the third week to the end of the eighth weekof IUL.
      • Key Events:
        • Differentiation of germ layers into specific body organs
        • Formation of placenta, umbilical cord, and extraembryonic membranes
      • Fetal Period
        • Duration: Beginning of the ninth week to birth.
        • Key Events:
          • Tremendous growth and specialization of body structures

Key takeaways: Prenatal development consists of the pre-embryonic period (conception to week 2), embryonic period (week 3 to week 8), and fetal period (week 9 to birth), with each stage involving key morphogenic events essential for growth and specialization.

questions.text: All of the following cell containing chromosome 44XY, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Spermatogenesis

  • Definition: The process of forming spermatozoa from primordial germ cells (PGCs)/spermatogonia in the seminiferous tubules of the testis.
  • Dormancy: PGCs remain dormant in the seminiferous tubules until puberty.
  • Initiation at Puberty: Upon reaching puberty, PGCs undergo a series of divisions to form spermatogonia.
  • Stages of Spermatogenesis:
    1. Spermatogonia (Diploid):
      • The initial germ cells that undergo mitosis.
    2. Primary Spermatocytes (Diploid):
      • Result from the division of spermatogonia and undergo meiosis I.
    3. Secondary Spermatocytes (Haploid):
      • Formed after meiosis I, these undergo meiosis II.
    4. Spermatids (Haploid):
      • Result from meiosis II; they undergo maturation.
    5. Spermatozoa (Haploid):
      • Mature sperm cells that are released into the seminiferous tubules.

Key takeaways:

A spermatid contains 23 chromosomes (22 autosomes + 1 sex chromosome X or Y) after meiosis, while the other cells listed (spermatogonium type A, spermatogonium type B, and primary spermatocyte) contain 44 autosomes and 2 sex chromosomes (44XY).

questions.text: At the time of ovulation the secondary oocyte is in which of the following stage of meiotic division?
questions.solution:
The secondary oocyte is arrested in metaphase II of the second meiotic division and will only complete it if fertilized

Oogenesis

  • Primary Oocyte Formation:
    • Primary oocytes enter the first meiotic division before birth and complete it at puberty, just before ovulation.
    • No new primary oocytes are formed after birth.
  • Secondary Oocyte Stage:
    • The secondary oocyte is in the metaphase stage of the second meiotic division at the time of ovulation and continues until fertilization.
    • The secondary oocyte completes its meiotic division only upon fertilization.
  • Oocyte Count:
    • At birth, the ovary contains approximately two million germ cells.
    • By puberty, this number decreases to about 40,000 oocytes due to degeneration.
  • Ovulation During Reproductive Life:
    • Approximately 400-500 ovarian follicles undergo ovulation during a woman's reproductive life (ages 12-50).
    • About 5-30 primary oocytes mature and complete their first meiotic division before ovulation in each cycle.

Key takeaways: At ovulation, the secondary oocyte is arrested in metaphase II of the second meiotic division and will only complete it if fertilized.

choices.text: It takes place within 24 hours of ovulation
It takes place in ampulla of the fallopian tube
It results into restoration of diploid number of chromosomes
It is fusion of primary oocyte with spermatozoon

questions.text: Which of the following is false about fertilization?
questions.solution:
It is false that fertilization is the fusion of a primary oocyte with a spermatozoon, as fertilization involves the fusion of a secondary oocyte (which has completed meiosis) with sperm.

  • Fertilization:
  • Definition: Fertilization is the fusion of male and female gametes (pronuclei) to form a zygote.
  • Process: It involves the fusion of the primary oocyte with a spermatozoon.
  • Timing: Fertilization occurs within 24 hours of ovulation.
  • Location: It takes place in the ampulla, the most dilated part of the uterine tube.
  • Results of Fertilization:
  • Genetic Sex Determination: The genetic sex of the embryo is established.
  • Restoration of Diploid Number: The diploid number of chromosomes is restored.
  • Initiation of Cleavage: Cleavage, the process of cell division, begins.
  • Importance: Fertilization is essential for the propagation of species and their evolution.

Key takeaways: Fertilization is the fusion of male and female gametes in the ampulla of the uterine tube within 24 hours of ovulation, forming a zygote and essential for genetic sex determination, restoration of the diploid chromosome number, cleavage initiation, and species propagation.

questions.text: During USG procedure snowstrom appearance of uterine cavity is seen in:
questions.solution:
Hydatidiform mole:

  • Common Blastocyst Abnormalities: Blighted blastocyst leads to embryo death.
  • Trophoblast Proliferation: Results in hyperplastic growth forming a hydatidiform mole (vesicular mass).
  • Villi Degeneration: Lack of blood supply prevents further development, causing cystic swellings.
  • HCG Levels: Moles secrete high levels of human chorionic gonadotrophins (HCG).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Preeclampsia in the first trimester
    • Elevated HCG (>100,000 mIU/ml)
    • Enlarged uterus and bleeding
    • Appearance resembles a bunch of grapes
    • Vesicles in urine
    • No fetal movements or heart sounds
    • Ultrasound shows snowstorm appearance in the uterine cavity.

Key takeaways: Blastocyst abnormalities can lead to a blighted blastocyst and hydatidiform mole, characterized by elevated HCG levels, preeclampsia, enlarged uterus, bleeding, and a snowstorm appearance on ultrasound.


SNOWSTORM appearance of hydatiform mole

choices.text: Epithelial lining of external auditory meatus
Epithelial lining of middle ear cavity

questions.text: Which of the following is not a derivative of ectoderm?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Epithelial lining of the external auditory meatus - Derived from ectoderm.
  • Option B: Epithelial lining of the middle ear cavity - Not derived from ectoderm; it is derived from the endoderm.
  • Option C: Epithelial lining of the nasal cavity - Derived from ectoderm.
  • Option D: Epithelial lining of the oral cavity - Derived from ectoderm.

Derivatives of three germ layers are as follow:


Key takeaways: The epithelial lining of the middle ear cavity is derived from the endoderm, while the other options (external auditory meatus, nasal cavity, and oral cavity) are derived from the ectoderm.

questions.text: Absence of intraembryonic mesoderm at all othe following sites, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Formation of Intraembryonic Mesoderm:

  • Primitive Streak Formation: Cells of the primitive streak invaginate toward the endoderm, creating the primitive groove on its surface.
  • Intraembryonic Mesoderm Development: Cells from the primitive streak spread between the endoderm and ectoderm, forming the intraembryonic mesoderm, the third germ layer.
  • Direction of Spread: The intraembryonic mesoderm expands cranially, caudally, and laterally into all areas of the embryonic disc except in three specific regions:
    • Prochordal Plate: Ectoderm and endoderm are in close contact, forming the buccopharyngeal membrane.
    • Cloacal Membrane: Located at the caudal end of the disc, where ectoderm and endoderm are also in intimate contact.
    • Notochord Region: Midline area between the prochordal plate and primitive knot, occupied by the notochord.

Key takeaways: Intraembryonic mesoderm forms from invaginating cells of the primitive streak, spreading between endoderm and ectoderm, except in the prochordal plate, cloacal membrane, and notochord regions where the germ layers remain in contact.

choices.text: End of 2nd week of intrauterine life
End of 3rd week of intrauterine life
End of 4th week of intrauterine life
End of 5th week of intrauterine life

questions.text: The primitive streak completeley disappears by the age of:
questions.solution:
The Primitive Streak:

  • Definition: A linear thickened band of ectodermal cells located at the caudal end of the embryo in the midline.
  • Formation: Results from the proliferation and migration of ectodermal cells on the embryonic disc's superior surface.
  • Characteristics: The cells of the primitive streak are pluripotent, capable of differentiating into various cell types.
  • Structures Derived:
    • Intraembryonic mesoderm
    • Septum transversum
    • Notochord
    • Determines the craniocaudal axis of the embryo
    • Demarcates the left and right halves of the embryo
  • Fate of the Primitive Streak:
    • Actively forms intraembryonic mesoderm through cell ingression until the end of the third week of intrauterine life (IUL).
    • Regresses craniocaudally and disappears by the end of the fourth week, or becomes insignificant in the sacrococcygeal region.

Key takeaways: The primitive streak is a midline band of ectodermal cells that forms key structures like intraembryonic mesoderm and notochord, determines the embryo's axes, and regresses by the end of the fourth week.

choices.text: Nucleus pulposus and apical ligament of dens
Apical ligament of dens and membranatectoria
Nucleus pulposus, apical ligament of dens and membranatectoria

questions.text: Which of the following are remnants of notochord?
questions.solution:
The notochord:

  • It is a midline structure that develops in the region between the primitive streak and the prochordal plate.
  • It develops from the primitive knot (Hensen's node) of the primitive streak
  • Functions of Notochord
    • It forms the central axis of the developing embryo (embryonic disc).
    • It induces the formation of neural tube from the overlying ectoderm.
    • It provides central column around which vertebral bodies and intervertebral discs develop.
  • Fate of Notochord
    • The notochord is present in all the animals belonging to phylum Chordata.
    • In human beings, it appears only in embryo. In later life, it disappears but its remnants are seen in the form of nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral discs and apical ligament of dens of second cervical vertebra.

Key takeaways:

questions.text: 1st pair of somites appears on which day of intrauterine life?
questions.solution:
Development of the Somites:

  • Definition: Somites are cubical blocks of mesoderm situated caudally to the otic vesicle on each side of the developing neural tube.
  • Onset: The first somite pair appears in the occipital region on Day 20, shortly after which subsequent pairs form in a craniocaudal
  • Formation Sequence:
    • Cranial somites are the oldest; caudal somites are the
    • Approximately 38 pairs of somites form between Days 20 and 30 of development (the somite period).
  • Total Somites: By the end of the fifth week (around 42 days), 44 pairs of somites are present:
    • 4 Occipital
    • 8 Cervical
    • 12 Thoracic
    • 5 Lumbar
    • 5 Sacral
    • 8 to 10 Coccygeal
  • Visual Identification: Somites create visible surface elevations on either side of the midline.
  • Development Rate: Approximately three pairs of somites are added daily until the fifth week, making the count of somites a useful index for determining the age of the embryo.

Key takeaways: Somites are cubical blocks of mesoderm located caudal to the otic vesicle, first appearing in the occipital region on day 20, with about 38 pairs forming between days 20 and 30, and totaling 44 pairs by the end of the fifth week, providing an index of the embryo's age.

choices.text: Septum transversum lies cranial to the pericardial cavity and heart tube
Cranial part of the neural plate lies above and behind the primitive buccopharyngeal membrane
Heart tube lies below the pericardial cavity

questions.text: All of the following is true about arrangements of the structure before folding of embryo, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Option A: True. The septum transversum is indeed located cranial to the pericardial cavity and heart tube during early embryonic development.
  • Option B: True. The cranial part of the neural plate is situated above and behind the primitive buccopharyngeal membrane.
  • Option C: True. The heart tube is positioned below the pericardial cavity.
  • Option D: Incorrect. The allantois does not extend ventrally; instead, it projects into the umbilical cord, eventually contributing to the formation of the bladder and umbilical blood vessels.

Arrangement of important structures of embryo before and after the folding in craniocaudal direction as follows:


Key takeaways:

The septum transversum is above the pericardial cavity, the cranial neural plate is behind the buccopharyngeal membrane, the heart tube is anterior to the pericardial cavity, and the allantois is a ventral outpouching forming part of the urinary bladder and umbilical cord.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about monozygotic twins?
questions.solution:
Option A: False. Monozygotic twins are typically either monozygotic (identical) and can be either diamniotic and monochorionic or monoamniotic and monochorionic, but not exclusively one type.

Option B: True. Monozygotic twins can be diamniotic and dichorionic, especially if the splitting occurs within the first 3 days after fertilization.

Option C: True. If the zygote splits later, typically between days 4-8, they can be monoamniotic and monochorionic.

Option D: True. Monozygotic twins can also be monoamniotic and dichorionic if the splitting occurs at a specific point.

Differences between monozygotic and dizygotic twins


Key takeaways:

Monozygotic twins can exhibit various configurations depending on the timing of zygotic splitting, resulting in diamniotic and dichorionic, or monoamniotic and monochorionic conditions. Understanding these differences is crucial in prenatal care and monitoring for potential complications.

questions.text: Which of the following period of intrauterine life is most sensitive to teratogens?
questions.solution:
• Periods of Susceptivity to Teratogenesis:
  • Fundamental concept of teratology is that clinician must know that certain periods of gestation (pregnancy) are more susceptible to teratogenesis than others.
  • In general, the periods of susceptibility to teratogens are divided into three groups as follows:

Key takeaways:

The most sensitive period for teratogen exposure is 3-8 weeks of intrauterine life, coinciding with major organ development. This critical window highlights the need for caution regarding harmful substances during pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following type of implantation seen in the human being?
questions.solution:
Implantation:

  • It is a process by which the embryo is embedded and fixed with the endometrium of the uterus.
  • Timing of implantation:
    • The implantation occurs during a restricted time period of 6-10 days after ovulation in humans.
  • Types of implantation:
    • Interstitial implantation: In this type, the blastocyst is embedded in the endometrium of the uterine wall (e.g., human).
    • Eccentric implantation: In this type, the blastocyst is embedded in the uterine crypts, e.g., rat.
    • Central implantation: In this type, the blastocyst is implanted in the uterine cavity, e.g., cow.
  • Abnormal Sites of Implantation: These may be within the uterus or outside the uterus.
    • Abnormal sites of implantation within the uterus: In the lower uterine segment near the internal os.
    • In the uterine tube (tubal implantation): Here it may take place in the ampulla, in the infundibulum, or in the interstitial part in order of frequency of occurrence.
    • In the abdominal cavity (abdominal implantation): Here it implants most frequently in the peritoneal lining of the rectouterine pouch (pouch of Douglas); but may implant at any place covered by peritoneum, e.g., mesentery.
    • In the ovary (ovarian implantation): Fertilization and implantation may occur while ovum is still within the ovary.

Key takeaways: Implantation is the process by which the embryo embeds in the uterine endometrium, occurring 6-10 days after ovulation, with types including interstitial, eccentric, and central implantation, while abnormal sites can include the lower uterine segment, uterine tube, abdominal cavity, and ovary.

questions.text: What is the type of human placenta?
questions.solution:
• In humans maternal blood is separated from fetal blood by chorionic tissue; hence human placenta is termed hemochorial.
  • Phylogenic classification of placenta:
    • It is based on maternal and fetal tissues that come in contact.
    • Phylogenetically the placenta is classified into following five types.

Key takeaways:

The human placenta is classified as hemochorial, where maternal blood is in direct contact with chorionic tissue. This classification is part of a broader phylogenetic system that categorizes placentas based on the interaction of maternal and fetal tissues.

questions.text: Stylopharyngeous is derived from which pharyngeal arch?
questions.solution:
The pharyngeal arch derivatives:

  • Muscles of first arch:
    • The muscles derived from first arch are muscles of mastication (viz., temporalis, masseter, lateral pterygoid, and medial pterygoid), anterior belly of digastric, mylohyoid, tensor tympani, and tensor palati.
    • All these muscles are supplied by mandibular nerve.
  • Muscles of second arch:
    • The muscles derived from second arch are muscles of the facial expression, posterior belly of digastric, stylohyoid, and stapedius.
    • All these muscles are supplied by facial nerve.
  • Muscles of third arch:
    • The only muscle derived from the third arch is stylopharyngeus.
    • It is supplied by glossopharyngeal nerve.
  • Muscles of Fourth arch:
    • The muscles derived from fourth arch are cricothyroid, levator veli palati, and constrictors of the pharynx.
    • They are supplied by superior laryngeal nerve.
  • Muscles of sixth arch:
    • The muscles of the larynx derived from sixth arch.
    • They are supplied by recurrent laryngeal nerve.

Key takeaways:

Stylopharyngeus muscle is derived from the third pharyngeal arch and is supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve. Each pharyngeal arch gives rise to specific muscle groups, with the first arch associated with mastication, the second with facial expression, and the fourth with pharyngeal constriction.

questions.text: Second pharangeal pouch gives development to:
questions.solution:
Derivatives of pharyngeal pouches:

Key takeaways:


The second pharyngeal pouch develops into the intratonsillar cleft and the palatine tonsil, which are important for throat anatomy. In contrast, the ultimopharyngeal body and superior parathyroid gland originate from the fourth pouch, while the inferior parathyroid gland arises from the third pouch.

questions.text: Circumvallate papillae of tongue deriverd from?
questions.solution:
Development of the Tongue

  • Formation of Anterior Two-Thirds:
    • The lateral lingual swellings overgrow the tuberculum impar and merge to form the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
    • The line of fusion creates the median sulcus.
    • The tuberculum impar does not contribute to the adult tongue.
  • Formation of Posterior One-Third:
    • The posterior one-third, including the circumvallate papillae, develops from the cranial part of the hypobranchial eminence.
    • A V-shaped groove(the sulcus terminalis) indicates the fusion line between the anterior and posterior parts.
    • The posterior most part of the tongue and the epiglottis arise from the caudal part of the hypobranchial eminence.

Key takeaways: The tongue develops from lateral swellings merging to form the anterior two-thirds, with the posterior part arising from the hypobranchial eminence, marked by the sulcus terminalis, and innervated by different cranial nerves based on pharyngeal arch origins.

questions.text: Which of the following anomaly will appear in the child due to failure of fusion of maxillary processes with the frontonasal process?
questions.solution:
Cleft lip:

  • Varieties of Cleft Upper Lip:
  • Unilateral Cleft Lip: Caused by failure of fusion between the maxillary process and the medial nasal process on the same side.
  • Bilateral Cleft Lip: Caused by failure of fusion between the maxillary processes and the frontonasal process.
  • Central Cleft Lip (Hair Lip): Results from failure in the development of the philtrum of the upper lip from the frontonasal process.
  • Cleft Lower Lip: Rare occurrence due to failure of fusion of the two mandibular processes in the midline.

Oblique Facial Cleft (Orbitofacial Fissure):

  • A rare congenital anomaly where the maxillary process fails to fuse with the lateral nasal process.
  • The fissure extends from the medial angle of the eye to the upper lip.
  • This condition exposes the nasolacrimal duct to the exterior and is usually bilateral.

Key takeaways:

Cleft upper lip can be unilateral, bilateral, or central, while oblique facial cleft, a rare anomaly, occurs due to the failure of fusion between the maxillary and lateral nasal processes, exposing the nasolacrimal duct.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a content of umbilical cord?
questions.solution:
The Umbilical Cord

  • Structure:
    • A cord-like structure connecting the fetus to the uterine wall via the placenta.
    • Extends from the umbilicus of the fetus to the center of the fetal surface of the placenta.
    • Covered by a glistening amniotic membrane.
  • Twisting and Features:
    • The cord is twisted and may present false knots.
  • Contents:
    • Two umbilical arteries: Carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.
    • One umbilical vein: Typically the left umbilical vein, carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.
    • Wharton's jelly: A gelatinous substance that provides cushioning.
    • Remains of allantoic diverticulum: A remnant of the allantois, involved in early excretion and respiration.
    • Remains of vitellointestinal duct: A remnant of the yolk sac.
  • Development:
    • The right umbilical vein typically disappears by the end of the first trimester.

Key takeaways: The umbilical cord connects the fetus to the placenta, containing two umbilical arteries, one left umbilical vein, Wharton's jelly, and remnants of the allantoic diverticulum and vitellointestinal duct, all encased in the amniotic membrane.
